title: 111_s652
content: The Act may be cited as the "Community Coalitions for Access and Quality Improvement Act of 2009" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The Act aims to assist community health coalitions in improving access to quality healthcare services through coordination, infrastructure development, and activities related to healthcare provision. The Act aims to assist community health coalitions in improving access to quality healthcare services through coordination and developing activities for individuals with chronic conditions. SEC. 3. GRANTS TO STRENGTHEN THE EFFECTIVENESS, EFFICIENCY, AND COORDINATION OF SERVICES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to develop integrated health care delivery systems for defined communities to improve efficiency, coordinate providers, prevent chronic diseases, and expand services. Eligible entities must represent a balanced consortium focused on sustainable provision of coordinated services for all residents. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to develop integrated health care delivery systems for defined communities. The grant application must include a consortium of providers, such as federally qualified health centers, rural health clinics, and rural health networks. The Secretary awards grants for integrated health care delivery systems in defined communities. The grant application must include providers like federally qualified health centers, rural health clinics, and networks. Applicants must meet specific criteria, including hospitals with a high low-income utilization rate, critical access hospitals, public health departments, and interested health care providers or organizations serving the uninsured and low-income individuals. Applicants must submit an application to the Secretary. The grant application for integrated health care delivery systems in defined communities must clearly define the community to be served, identify participating providers, describe proposed activities, and demonstrate the coalition's ability to build on the current system. The coalition must demonstrate the ability to develop coordinated systems of care that provide a broad range of high-quality services, involve the community, including the business community, and ensure continuity of care. The coalition must ensure individuals are enrolled in health coverage programs, leverage various revenue sources for sustainability, and have a plan for evaluating program activities to improve system performance. The eligible entity must demonstrate fiscal responsibility and commitment to serving the community by providing free or reduced charge care for the poor. An entity may receive a grant for up to 3 consecutive fiscal years and request an extension for 2 additional years. In awarding grants under this section, the Secretary may prioritize applicants with the greatest unmet need for coordinated care and those who best promote the objectives of the program. The applicant must demonstrate inclusion of community providers serving uninsured or low-income individuals, expand preventive and primary care services, and propose approaches to improve healthcare access for the underserved. The applicant must demonstrate collaboration with State and local governments, use non-Federal contributions to the greatest extent possible, and show likelihood of sustainable integrated delivery system development. Grantees may use funds for direct expenses associated with healthcare services. The grant funds can be used for direct expenses related to integrating a healthcare delivery system to provide culturally competent services and fill gaps in patient care within the system. The grant funds can be used for various purposes including increasing outreach activities, improving care management, coordinating transportation to health care facilities, and developing provider networks. Development of common processes such as eligibility determination for programs provided through the system, recruitment, training, and compensation of personnel, and coordination of technology use for improved care and provider communication within a community. Development of prevention and disease management tools, language access services, involvement of community organizations for better healthcare access, and overcoming barriers in the healthcare system for prompt diagnosis and treatment resolution. The section discusses the allocation of funds for direct patient care, national program purposes, and reporting requirements for grantees under the program. The grantee's progress in meeting goals and objectives set in the grant application is evaluated based on the effectiveness, efficiency, and coordination of services for uninsured and low-income individuals. The impact on the quality of healthcare provided and cost savings are also assessed. The Secretary may award a grant under this section only if the applicant and providers agree to maintain their non-Federal fund expenditures at or above the previous fiscal year level. Technical assistance may be provided to grant recipients by the Secretary through grants or contracts with organizations experienced in community coalition building. The Secretary will evaluate the success of projects funded under this section in improving services in communities, including quality healthcare provision at lower costs. Authorization of appropriations is set at $75,000,000 for 2010, $100,000,000 for 2011, and $125,000,000 for 2012. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014 are set at $125,000,000, $150,000,000, and $175,000,000 respectively.
